Clearly, any critical point of J on Sρ is a normalized solution of (1). If f admits a L2 subcritical growth, i.e., f has a growth up−1 with p < 2∗ := 2 + 4 N , then J |Sρ is bounded below and one can use the minimization method to get a global minimizer [9, 12, 18, 26]. If f admits a L2 supercritical growth, i.e., p > 2∗, then J |Sρ is unbounded below. Consequently, the direct minimization on Sρ does not work and different approaches are required. Indeed, in 1997, Jeanjean [20] developed a mountain-pass argument for the scaled functional J̃ (u, s) := J (s ⋆ u) with s ⋆ u(·) := e Ns 2 u(es·) to study the L2 supercritical problems. Subsequently, Bartsch and de Valerioda [6] applied the fountain theorem to J̃ and obtained infinitely many normalized solutions of (1). In [19], Ikoma and Tanaka established a deformation result for the L2 normalized
solutions and gave an alternative proof of the results in [6, 20]. We note that the following conditions are important in these studies:

The Ambrosetti-Rabinowitz condition was not assumed in [10], and the results were established under the following condition:

In particular, in [1], the authors proved the existence of normalized ground state solutions to (1) under the assumption (6) with α0 = 4π for ρ ∈ (0, 1) and some suitable conditions on f , where the Ambrosetti-Rabinowitz condition plays a crucial role.
It is natural to ask if one can show the existence of normalized ground state solutions to (1) for the exponential critical nonlinearity without the Ambrosetti-Rabinowitz condition in the case of N = 2. The goal of this paper is to give an affirmative answer to this question. Inspired by [10, 23, 25], for any ρ > 0, we will apply a minimization argument to prove the existence of normalized ground state solutions to (1) under a weak monotonicity condition.
For more studies on normalized solutions of nonlinear Schrödinger equations, we refer to [21, 22, 24, 27–29] and the references therein.
